common

Class ImageFileInputStream

  • java.lang.Object
    • common.ImageFileInputStream
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.AutoCloseable

    public class ImageFileInputStream
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.AutoCloseable
    A utility stream wrapper that simplifies reading binary image data from an InputStream, with support for both big-endian and little-endian formats.

    This class provides methods to read signed and unsigned values of various primitive types, for example, readShort(), readUnsignedInteger() or readFloat()), while tracking the current read position.

    Change History:

    • Version 1.0 - Initial release by Trevor Maggs on 21 June 2025
    Since:
    21 June 2025
    Version:
    0.1
    Author:
    Trevor Maggs

      • readInternal

        private int readInternal()
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Reads the next single byte of data from the stream and returns as an integer between 0 and 255. If EOF is reached, a value of -1 is returned.
        Returns:
        the value of the next byte in the stream, or a value of -1 if EOF is hit
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error has occurred

      • readInternal

        private int readInternal(byte[] buf,
                         int offset,
                         int len)
                  throws java.io.IOException
        Reads up to len bytes from the stream into the buffer starting at the specified offset.
        Parameters:
        buf - the destination byte array
        offset - the starting position in the buffer
        len - the number of bytes to read
        Returns:
        the number of bytes read, or -1 if end of stream is reached
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if buf is null
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset or len are invalid

      • setByteOrder

        public void setByteOrder(java.nio.ByteOrder order)
        Specifies the required byte order that determines how byte values are read from the stream.

        For instance, when reading the sequence of bytes '0x01 0x02 0x03 0x04' (which represents a 4-byte integer), it would be interpreted as '0x01020304' in big-endian (network) byte order, or '0x04030201' in little-endian byte order.

        A value of iByteOrder.BIG_ENDIAN specifies big-endian or network byte order, where the high-order byte comes first. Processors like Motorola and Sparc store data in this format, while Intel processors use little-endian byte reverse order, represented by ByteOrder.LITTLE_ENDIAN.

        Parameters:
        order - either ByteOrder.BIG_ENDIAN or ByteOrder.LITTLE_ENDIAN
        See Also:
        for more details

      • getByteOrder

        public java.nio.ByteOrder getByteOrder()
        Returns the current byte order used by this stream when reading multi-byte values. The byte order determines how the stream interprets the sequence of bytes—either as big-endian (most significant byte first) or little-endian (least significant byte first).
        Returns:
        the byte order used for reading, either ByteOrder.BIG_ENDIAN or ByteOrder.LITTLE_ENDIAN
        See Also:
        for more details on byte order conventions

      • getCurrentPosition

        public long getCurrentPosition()
        Returns the current byte position of the stream. The next read operation will take place starting at this position.
        Returns:
        the position of the stream

      • readByte

        public byte readByte()
              throws java.io.IOException
        Reads a single byte from the stream and returns it as a signed byte value. Byte values between 0x00 and 0x7F correspond to integer values between 0 and 127, while values between 0x80 and 0xFF represent negative values ranging from -128 to -1.
        Returns:
        a signed byte value from the stream
        Throws:
        java.io.EOFException - if the end of the stream is reached
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • readUnsignedByte

        public int readUnsignedByte()
                     throws java.io.IOException
        Reads a single byte and returns it as an unsigned integer between 0 and 255.
        Returns:
        the unsigned byte value
        Throws:
        java.io.EOFException - if the end of the stream is reached
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs

      • readBytes

        public byte[] readBytes(int length)
                 throws java.io.IOException
        Reads data from the input stream into an array of bytes. It attempts to read up to the specified length, but may read fewer.
        Parameters:
        length - the maximum number of bytes to read
        Returns:
        an array of bytes that has been read
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if there is a problem, such as an unacceptable length or an I/O error or if the stream is closed

      • readShort

        public short readShort()

        Returns:
        the short value read from the stream
        Throws:
        java.io.EOFException - if the stream ends prematurely
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs

        Throws:

      • skip

        public long skip(long n)
          throws java.io.IOException
        Skips up to n bytes in the stream and returns the number of bytes actually skipped. This method ensures the requested number of bytes is skipped by repeatedly invoking InputStream.skip(long) until complete, or until EOF is reached.
        Parameters:
        n - the number of bytes to skip
        Returns:
        the actual number of bytes skipped
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs
        See Also:
        Learn why this logic is necessary

      • close

        public void close()
           throws java.io.IOException
        Closes this input stream and releases any system resources associated with it. Once closed, further read operations on this stream will throw an IOException. This method invokes the underlying InputStream's close() method.
        Specified by:
        close in interface java.lang.AutoCloseable
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an I/O error occurs while closing the stream
